text: ROTCE was 25%.
CET1 capital ratios were 13.8% for Standardized and 13.9% for Advanced.
Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity was $494B.
Standardized RWA was $1.7T.
Cash and marketable securities were $1.4T.
Average loans were $1.2T.
Income statement highlights include a 2Q23 net income of $14.5B and EPS of $4.75. Excluding significant items, net income was $13.3B, EPS was $4.37, and ROTCE was 23%.
Managed revenue was $42.4B, with expense of $20.8B and a managed overhead ratio of 49%.
Balance sheet highlights include average loans of $1.2T, up 13% YoY and 10% QoQ. Excluding the First Republic (FR) impact, average loans were $1.1T, up 4% YoY and 1% QoQ.
Average deposits were $2.4T, down 6% YoY and up 3% QoQ. Excluding FR, average deposits were $2.3T, down 8% YoY and up 1% QoQ.
CET1 capital stood at $236B, with a standardized CET1 capital ratio of 13.8% and an advanced CET1 capital ratio of 13.9%.
Capital distributed includes a common dividend of $2.9B or $1.00 per share, and $1.8B of common stock net repurchases.
Net payout for the last twelve months (LTM) was 32%.
Continued progress on migration: The FDIC and transaction settlement process is on schedule.
Branches: 21 branches were left behind with the FDIC, while the remaining 63 are being evaluated for conversion to Chase, JPM Wealth Management, or consolidation.
Systems integration: The full migration plan to JPMC systems is being developed, with a target for substantial completion in mid-2024.
Employee Engagement: Approximately 5,100 former FRC employees were onboarded on July 2, 2023, with 85% invited and 91% accepting.
The focus is on getting the sales force back in the market to win back customers.
Client Retention: Strong client retention has been observed, with $6B in net deposit inflows since the acquisition.
Customer fund flows indicate trust in the company's balance sheet and strength.
There is an opportunity to outperform original expectations and accelerate the affluent strategy.
Excluding the First Republic (FR) impact, net income was $5.0B, up 61% YoY.
Excluding FR, revenue of $16.4B was up 31% YoY, driven by higher net interest income.
Excluding FR, expense of $8.3B was up 8% YoY, largely due to higher compensation, marketing, wage inflation and headcount growth, partially offset by lower auto lease depreciation.
Excluding FR, credit costs were $1.5B, with net charge-offs (NCOs) of $1.3B, up $640mm YoY, mainly from Card Services.
Excluding FR, a reserve build of $203mm was driven by loan growth in Card Services and macroeconomic factors.
Excluding FR, average loans were up 5% YoY and 2% QoQ.
Excluding FR, average deposits were down 6% YoY and flat QoQ, while end-of-period deposits were down 6% YoY and 4% QoQ.
Excluding FR, active mobile customers were up 10% YoY, debit & credit card sales volume was up 7% YoY, and client investment assets were up 18% YoY and 7% QoQ.
Net income was $4.1B, up 10% YoY, and revenue was $12.5B, up 4% YoY.
IB revenue of $1.5B was up 11% YoY, while IB fees were down 6% YoY due to lower advisory fees.
Payments revenue of $2.5B was up 61% YoY, or 32% excluding equity investment impacts, driven by higher rates.
Lending revenue of $299mm was down 27% YoY, driven by mark-to-market losses on loan hedges.
Markets revenue of $7.0B was down 10% YoY.
Fixed Income Markets revenue was $4.6B, down 3% YoY, while Equity Markets revenue was $2.5B, down 20% YoY compared to a strong prior-year quarter.
Securities Services revenue was $1.2B, up 6% YoY, driven by higher rates.
Expense of $6.9B was up 1% YoY, driven by higher non-compensation expenses.
Credit costs were $38mm.
Excluding the First Republic (FR) impact, net income was $1.5B, up 54% YoY.

Excluding FR, revenue was $3.8B, up 42% YoY, driven by higher deposit margins, partially offset by lower deposit-related fees. Payments revenue was $2.2B, up 79% YoY, while Investment Banking and Markets revenue was down 3% YoY.
Excluding FR, expense of $1.3B was up 12% YoY, due to higher compensation and technology investments.
Excluding FR, credit costs were $489mm, with a reserve build of $389mm related to office real estate and Middle Market downgrades.
Excluding FR, average loans were $242B, up 10% YoY and 2% QoQ.
Excluding FR, average deposits were $275B, down 8% YoY but up 3% QoQ, driven by new client acquisition inflows.
Excluding the First Republic (FR) impact, net income was $1.1B, up 10% YoY.
Excluding FR, revenue of $4.6B was up 8% YoY, driven by higher deposit margins and management fees on strong net inflows.
Excluding FR, expense of $3.2B was up 8% YoY, driven by higher compensation.
Excluding FR, Assets Under Management (AUM) of $3.2T were up 16% YoY and client assets of $4.6T were up 20% YoY, driven by net inflows and market levels.
For the quarter, AUM had long-term net inflows of $61B and liquidity net inflows of $60B.
Excluding FR, average loans of $210B were down 3% YoY and 1% QoQ.
Excluding FR, average deposits of $212B were down 21% YoY and 6% QoQ.
Excluding the First Republic (FR) impact, revenue was $1.0B, up $905mm YoY.
Excluding FR, net interest income was $1.8B, compared with $324mm in the prior year, due to higher rates.
Excluding FR, noninterest revenue was a loss of $782mm, compared with a loss of $244mm in the prior year, and included $900mm of net investment securities losses.
Excluding FR, expense of $590mm was up $384mm YoY, largely driven by higher legal expense.
Excluding FR, credit costs were a net benefit of $243mm, reflecting a reserve release associated with a deposit placed with First Republic Bank in the first quarter of 2023.
Expect FY2023 net interest income and net interest income excluding Markets of ~$87B, market dependent.
Expect FY2023 adjusted expense of ~$84.5B excluding the FDIC special assessment related to systemic risk determination, market dependent.
Expect FY2023 Card Services NCO rate of ~2.60%.
The Firm's results are analyzed on a reported (GAAP) basis and a "managed" (non-GAAP) basis. The managed basis presents revenue on a fully taxable-equivalent basis.

Metrics excluding CIB Markets (composed of Fixed Income Markets and Equity Markets) are reviewed to assess performance of lending, investing, and deposit-raising activities separate from market volatility.

Second-quarter 2023 significant items, which are non-GAAP measures, include a $2.7B bargain purchase gain from First Republic, a $1.2B net credit reserve build for First Republic, and $900mm in net investment securities losses.
Tangible common equity (TCE), return on tangible common equity (ROTCE), and tangible book value per share (TBVPS) are non-GAAP measures used to assess the Firm's use of equity.
Adjusted expense and adjusted overhead ratio are non-GAAP measures that exclude certain Firmwide legal expenses to provide an alternate view of performance.
Corporate & Investment Bank (CIB) calculates the allowance for loan losses to end-of-period loans (ALL/EOP) ratio excluding certain items for a more meaningful assessment of allowance coverage.
Note 1 explains the phase-out of the Current Expected Credit Losses (CECL) capital benefit, which started on January 1, 2022, at a rate of 25% per year over three years.
Note 2 defines total excess high-quality liquid assets (HQLA) as average eligible unencumbered liquid assets exceeding requirements under the liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) rule.

Note 3 states that in 1Q23, allocations of revenue and expense to CCB from a Merchant Services agreement were discontinued and are now retained in Payments in CIB, with prior periods revised for conformity.
Note 4 indicates that prior-period amounts have been revised to conform with the current presentation, using end-of-period HQLA metrics.

Slide 5 - Consumer & Community Banking: Provides clarifications on the treatment of First Republic (FR) numbers, definition of mobile users, exclusion of Commercial Card, inclusion of PPP loans, and Firmwide mortgage origination volumes.

Slide 6 - Corporate & Investment Bank: Provides details on the basis of reported numbers, definitions of client deposits, merchant processing volume, composition of the bridge book and Securitized Products Group, and loan loss calculation exclusions.

Slide 7 - Commercial Banking: Details the treatment of FR numbers, reclassification of certain revenues in prior periods, revenue sharing arrangements with CIB, PPP loan impact, loan loss calculation exclusions, and definitions for C&I and CRE groupings.
